docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration will give American businesses far greater license to make investments in Myanmar, responding to the country’s political and economic opening over the last year.

headline.seo: White House to Ease Ban on Investment in Myanmar
headline.main: As Relations Warm With Myanmar, U.S. Will Ease Trade Limits
headline.print_headline: White House to Ease Ban on Investment in Myanmar

docs.abstract: Obama administration lifts most prohibitions on American businesses seeking to make investments in Myanmar, responding to the country's political and economic opening over the past year; changes are expected to usher in a new era of diplomatic relations between the United States and what was until recently one of the world’s most repressive countries.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration will give American businesses far greater license to make investments in Myanmar, responding to the country’s political and economic opening over the last year.

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- It is increasingly conceivable that Greece may leave the euro zone, not just because of its own political dysfunction but also because the consequences of such an exit for the rest of the Europe and the global economy no longer seem quite so scary. The foot-dragging and brinkmanship of the last few years have won the other members of the currency union valuable time to prepare for life without Greece. Banks have recorded losses on Greek investments, companies are making contingency plans and Europe has bolstered rescue funds for other vulnerable nations like Portugal, Ireland and Spain.

headline.main: A Greek Exit? Europe May Be Ready

docs.lead_paragraph: Georgetown University, a Jesuit institution, is being rebuked by local bishops after inviting Kathleen Sebelius, the health secretary and a supporter of abortion rights, to speak at commencement.

headline.main: New Fight on a Speaker at a Catholic University
headline.print_headline: New Fight on a Speaker At a Catholic University

docs.abstract: Archdiocese of Washington issues letter censuring Georgetown University for inviting Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, to speak at an awards ceremony; Sebelius, a Catholic, has been vilified by church leaders for upholding the mandate in the health care overhaul that requires even religiously affiliated institutions to provide birth control coverage to their employees.
docs.snippet: Georgetown University, a Jesuit institution, is being rebuked by local bishops after inviting Kathleen Sebelius, the health secretary and a supporter of abortion rights, to speak at commencement.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called for John F. Kennedy to issue a second Emancipation Proclamation in 1962.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof David W Blight and graduate student Allison Scharfstein draws attention to 1962 manifesto by Rev Dr Martin Luther King Jr that called on Pres John F Kennedy to issue an executive order outlawing segregation, calling it a 'second Emancipation Proclamation;' contends it offers a powerful defense of moral leadership that remains pertinent in the current climate of partisan deadlock.
docs.snippet: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called for John F. Kennedy to issue a second Emancipation Proclamation in 1962.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro Espada Jr. was convicted of stealing from a health care network, but jurors failed to agree on four other counts.

headline.seo: U.S. Expected to Retry Espada and Son on Fraud Counts
headline.main: U.S. Expected to Retry Ex-Senator on 4 Unresolved Charges
headline.print_headline: U.S. Is Expected to Retry Espada and His Son on Unresolved Charges in Fraud Case

docs.abstract: Federal prosecutors plan to attempt to recover nearly $500,000 that former Democratic state senator, Pedro Espada Jr, was convicted of stealing from a nonprofit health care network; also, they are seeking a retrial for Espada and his son; Espada has already been found guilty on four counts; son Pedro G Espada will be retried on all eight counts.
docs.snippet: Pedro Espada Jr. was convicted of stealing from a health care network, but jurors failed to agree on four other counts.

docs.lead_paragraph: The trading losses suffered by JPMorgan Chase have surged in recent days, surpassing the bank's initial $2 billion estimate by at least $1 billion, according to people with knowledge of the losses. When Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan's chief executive, announced the losses last Thursday, he indicated they could double within the next few quarters. But that process has been compressed into four trading days as hedge funds and other investors take advantage of JPMorgan's distress, fueling faster deterioration in the underlying credit market positions held by the bank.

headline.main: JPMorgan Loss Is Said to Rise At Least 50%

docs.abstract: Trading losses suffered by JPMorgan Chase have surged, surpassing bank's initial $2 billion estimate by at least $1 billion; investors have been taking advantage of its distress, accelerating deterioration of bank's position; Federal Reserve is examining the scope of the growing losses and the original bet, along with whether the bank took inappropriate risks. Photo (M)
